section.title: be going to
section.sectiontitle: Use be going to for personal intentions (an intention is a strong wish to do something in the future).
section.text1a: I'm going to get thinner next year.
section.text2a: We're going to visit Poland next summer.
section.sectiontitle2: We can use be going to for impersonal intentions.
section.text3a: Spain and Morocco are going to build a tunnel.
section.text4a: They are going to close the factory next year.

section.title: be going to
section.sectiontitle: Use the correct form of be + going to + verb.
section.text1a: I am going to, he/she/it is going to, we/you/they are going to
section.text2a: I am going to get a car and she is going to get a motorbike.
section.sectiontitle2: Use the contracted forms 'm/'s/'re going to in spoken English.
section.text3a: I'm going to visit them and they're going to take me to the mountains.
section.text4a: She's going to see the doctor.

section.title: Form questions with am/is/are + subject + going to
section.text1a: Are you going to have a party for your birthday?
section.text2a: Is it going to be cold in Toronto?
section.sectiontitle2: We form negatives with am/is/are + not + going to. We usually use the contractions I'm not, isn't and aren't in spoken English.
section.text3a: He isn't going to retire next year.
section.text4a: I'm not going to go to university.
